docs.snippet: It's a rare restaurant that stocks vintage beers, usually dark stouts, strong ales, barley wines and farmhouse ''bières de garde.'' But Kevin Garry, the assistant beverage director of Gramercy Tavern, enlisted Garrett Oliver, the brewmaster of th...
docs.abstract: Gramercy Tavern in Manhattan is stocking supply of vintage beers and ciders; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: It's a rare restaurant that stocks vintage beers, usually dark stouts, strong ales, barley wines and farmhouse ''bières de garde.'' But Kevin Garry, the assistant beverage director of Gramercy Tavern, enlisted Garrett Oliver, the brewmaster of the Brooklyn Brewery, to help him assemble a list of 25 vintage beers, along with a few vintage ciders, to serve in the restaurant's cafe and formal dining room for $10 to $50 a bottle (sizes vary). Most are deep amber to ebony and taste of caramel, coffee and roasted nuts.

headline.main: A Chance to Sample Vintage, Yes, Beers

docs.snippet: Amid the jumble of preserves, biscuits, sweets, condiments, teas and gift items in Chelsea Market Baskets in Chelsea Market, David Porat, the owner, has found space for a well-edited selection of fine cheeses.     Matt Ross, right, who had been at...
docs.abstract: Chelsea Market Baskets creates space with well-edited selection of cheeses; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Amid the jumble of preserves, biscuits, sweets, condiments, teas and gift items in Chelsea Market Baskets in Chelsea Market, David Porat, the owner, has found space for a well-edited selection of fine cheeses. Matt Ross, right, who had been at Bedford Cheese in Brooklyn, runs the counter, where he offers no more than about two dozen varieties: soft-ripening, hard, Cheddar, blue and fresh goat, representing America, England, Italy, France and Spain.

headline.main: Cheese at Chelsea Market: Select but Choice

docs.snippet: You can give your kitchen counter a stunning splash of color with this pair of mixing bowls, designed by Jan Hoekstra for the Museum of Modern Art's gift shop. The small one holds a liter, about a quart, and the larger one takes two and one-half l...
docs.abstract: Jan Hoekstra designs pair of mixing bowls for Museum of Modern Art's gift shop; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: You can give your kitchen counter a stunning splash of color with this pair of mixing bowls, designed by Jan Hoekstra for the Museum of Modern Art's gift shop. The small one holds a liter, about a quart, and the larger one takes two and one-half liters, indicated by graduated markings in metric measures and ounces on the inside. There's a nonskid ring on the bottom and their streamlined shape and excellent balance make holding and lifting to pour batter or broth very easy. They are dishwasher-safe and sell for $30 a set at the museum's shops, and at (800) 447-6662 or moma.org.

headline.main: When Measuring Becomes a Term of Art

docs.snippet: There's a little more variety in sweet potatoes this fall. Small fingerling sweet potatoes in various colors can be simply roasted, then piled attractively in a bowl or on a platter. They can be peeled and steamed and, since having crisp skin is n...
docs.abstract: Availability of small fingerling sweet potatoes in various colors noted; photos (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: There's a little more variety in sweet potatoes this fall. Small fingerling sweet potatoes in various colors can be simply roasted, then piled attractively in a bowl or on a platter. They can be peeled and steamed and, since having crisp skin is not as important with such small potatoes, they can also be cooked in a microwave oven. The red ones, called Beauregard Reds, top, have dark orange flesh and are the sweetest. The orange-skinned Jewels, bottom right, are also orange inside, but a trifle less sweet. Most intriguing were the Hannah Sweets, center left, which had beige skin, lemon-yellow flesh and a flavor that suggested chestnuts. They were fairly dry-textured and delicious doused with butter.

headline.main: Red, Orange And Yellow: Shades Of Sweet

docs.snippet: There is an ice-cream flavor for each New York City borough at 5 Boroughs Ice Cream, a new little company in Astoria, Queens, owned by Scott Myles, a graphic designer, and his wife, Kim, a hairdresser. The cream comes from local dairies.     Bakla...
docs.abstract: Five Boroughs Ice Cream in Astoria, Queens, has created flavors paying homage to each New York City borough; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: There is an ice-cream flavor for each New York City borough at 5 Boroughs Ice Cream, a new little company in Astoria, Queens, owned by Scott Myles, a graphic designer, and his wife, Kim, a hairdresser. The cream comes from local dairies. Bakla-Wha?!, the flavor that represents Queens (and the Greek population of Astoria), has bits of toasty phyllo and walnuts in a creamy vanilla base; it's my hands-down favorite. Cha Cha Chocolate, the Bronx flavor, kicks in with chili-based heat. Staten Island Landfill is riddled with swaths of fudge, pieces of brownie and cherries.

headline.main: An Ice-Cream Maker Defines the Boroughs

docs.snippet: Sardinia has its own assertively rustic cuisine, like the crisp shepherd's bread called pane carasau, made in big crackerlike disks. Try brushing the bread with oil and lightly toasting it, or layering it with tomato sauce and cheese to make a qui...
docs.abstract: Bread and honey from Sardinia is available through Gourmet Sardinia; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Sardinia has its own assertively rustic cuisine, like the crisp shepherd's bread called pane carasau, made in big crackerlike disks. Try brushing the bread with oil and lightly toasting it, or layering it with tomato sauce and cheese to make a quick lasagnalike dish. A two-pound box from Gourmet Sardinia (gourmetsardinia.com) is $15.99, plus shipping.

docs.snippet: Magenta-red radishes selling for $1 a bunch at the Union Square Greenmarket are easily the size of limes. Super Bunny might want to munch on them raw, but why not cook them?     I cut each of 12 radishes in eighths vertically, heated two tablespoo...
docs.abstract: Oversized radishes are now offered by several farmers at Union Square Greenmarket; cooking instructions noted; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Magenta-red radishes selling for $1 a bunch at the Union Square Greenmarket are easily the size of limes. Super Bunny might want to munch on them raw, but why not cook them? I cut each of 12 radishes in eighths vertically, heated two tablespoons of olive oil in a skillet and sautéed the pieces, turning them frequently, until they became slightly translucent and crisp-tender. Then I added four tablespoons of crème fraîche and some salt and pepper and let them cook a few minutes longer.

docs.snippet: It looks like a tiny Venetian carnival mask with a winsome smile, but the new stainless steel corn zipper, made by Kuhn Rikon, is an effective gadget for summer cooking. Knives can cut into the cob even when used by the steadiest hand, but the cor...
docs.abstract: Kuhn Rikon makes gadget for stripping corn from cob; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: It looks like a tiny Venetian carnival mask with a winsome smile, but the new stainless steel corn zipper, made by Kuhn Rikon, is an effective gadget for summer cooking. Knives can cut into the cob even when used by the steadiest hand, but the corn zipper's little teeth precisely separate the kernels from the cob so that they drop into a bowl. The corn zipper is around $11.95 at Broadway Panhandler, Gracious Home and at Art of Cooking.

headline.main: Undressing the Corn, With a Smile

docs.snippet: A special oven, above, has started punching out pita bread at top speed at Yummy Schwarmy, 71 Seventh Avenue South (Bleecker Street), a bright new eat-in and takeout spot owned by Kobi Weichman, above right. Middle Eastern shwarma -- chicken or tu...
docs.abstract: Yummy Schwarma in Greenwich Village is takeout place where customers feast on pita stuffed with variety of fillings; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: A special oven, above, has started punching out pita bread at top speed at Yummy Schwarmy, 71 Seventh Avenue South (Bleecker Street), a bright new eat-in and takeout spot owned by Kobi Weichman, above right. Middle Eastern shwarma -- chicken or turkey cooked on vertical spits -- is sliced and stuffed into the pitas or into freshly baked baguettes to make sandwiches ($5.50).

headline.main: Mideastern Treat: Shwarma, By the Swarm

docs.snippet: John-Paul Lee and Sonny Caberwal are 20-somethings who have set out to make tea hip. They even hired a D.J. for their new little shop, Tavalon Tea Bar, at 22 East 14th Street, and have a tea sommelier, Chris Cason, to help customers. Along one wal...
docs.abstract: Tavalon Tea Bar in Flatiron district (NYC) offers variety of teas with specialized service of tea sommelier; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: John-Paul Lee and Sonny Caberwal are 20-somethings who have set out to make tea hip. They even hired a D.J. for their new little shop, Tavalon Tea Bar, at 22 East 14th Street, and have a tea sommelier, Chris Cason, to help customers. Along one wall of the sleekly designed sliver of a store is an array of about 30 teas packed in tins (all $8, with 1 to 2.5 ounces), and tea-brewing equipment. Want to sniff first? Tea samples come in test tubes. At the rear is a counter for ordering hot and cold drinks ($2.75 to $4). Pastries from 'wichcraft, Amai Tea & Bake House and Balthazar Bakery include a tender green-tea cupcake ($3): (212) 807-7027. Teas can be ordered at tavalon.com beginning next month.

headline.main: On East 14th Street, It's Always Time for Tea
